description: The latest solo project from Labradord's Mark Nelson is proof of how ambient music can benefit from a songwriter's disciplined ear and instinct for concision.

title: Static Tensions
label: Prosthetic
description: Like fellow Georgians Mastodon and Baroness, Kylesa have brilliantly alloyed sludge metal with melody and finesse.

title: Pierced
label: Naxos
description: Bang on a Can co-leader makes a refreshing and rare foray into solo territory.

title: Born Radical
label: Gangplank
description: Ryan Allen of Thunderbirds Are Now! returns with a vigorously played song cycle about the life of a rock journeyman.

title: The Floodlight Collective
label: Kranky
description: Deerhunter guitarist makes his solo debut, a hazy bedroom reverie that shouldn't surprise listeners accustomed to his main band. Bradford Cox guests.

title: Fever Ray
label: Mute
description: Three years after the landmark Silent Shout, the Knife's Karin Dreijer Andersson returns as Fever Ray. Fans of the Knife will not be disappointed.

title: White Light Strobing
label: K
description: Pacific NW band crafts word-shy, languid dream-pop in the style of Galaxie 500, heavy on atmosphere and gently cascading guitars.

title: Take My Breath Away
label: Kompakt
description: Brazilian producer's follow-up to 2007's excellent Chromophobia is another fusion of rock dynamics, synth-pop textures, and techno propulsion.

title: Enemy Mine
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Second album from the indie rock supergroup comprised of Dan Bejar, Spencer Krug, and Carey Mercer is more balanced and inclusive than its predecessor.

title: The Wolf Also Shall Dwell With the Lamb
label: Important
description: James Blackshaw, today's foremost guitarist in the modern primitive tradition, teams with lutist Jozef van Wissem. Insert RenFair joke here.

title: Flood Bank
label: Acute
description: The EPs and singles by this sadly unheralded post-punk group finally saw the light of day on Memory Span; here their LPs are collected as well.

title: Quiet Please...The New Best of Nick Lowe
label: Yep Roc
description: Not to be confused with the 1989 best-of Basher, this new comp presents a fuller view of the diverse singer-songwriter's career.

title: Bromst
label: Carpark
description: After breakthough Spiderman of the Rings, Dan Deacon returns with another great record whose palette is richer, the samples smoother, the space larger.

title: All Aboard Future
label: Dead Oceans
description: If the Yeah Yeah Yeahs had pursued the more confrontational branches of New York no-wave, they would probably sound like this.

title: Beasts of Seasons
label: Hush
description: The Pac NW coughs up folksy, understated singer-songwriters by the coffeehouseful, but this Portland-based singer shouldn't become lost in that crowd.

title: Heavy Ghost
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: A designer by trade, this My Brightest Diamond protégé is proving himself an adept songwriter as well.

title: Fist of God
label: Dim Mak
description: Latest from half of the sadly departed DFA79 always seems to be shouting over itself, a tone that accounts for its virtues and shortcomings alike.

title: Baby, They Told Us We Would Rise Again
label: SCI Fidelity
description: Recent Drive-By Truckers openers issues their eighth album in 23 years of hauling ass around the country, playing to every kind of crowd.

title: To Lose My Life...
label: Fiction
description: Lots of bands emulate bits of Joy Division. Sometimes they're Radiohead, sometimes they're Interpol, and, alas, sometimes they're White Lies.

title: Coward
label: Cryptogramophone
description: Spinning through delicate acoustics, genre homages, abstract meditations, and electro-funk, Wilco guitarist Nels Cline offers an eclectic new LP.

title: I Blame You
label: Sub Pop
description: Former Drive Like Jehu and Hot Snakes singer/guitarist Rick Froberg unveils his new Sub Pop project.

title: Why There Are Mountains
label: self-released
description: Plucking influences from 90s indie rock isn't new, but Cymbals Eat Guitars perfectly embody that casually ambitious slack-rock sound. Sometimes you just want the basics.

title: The Otha Side of the Trap...
label: Asylum
description: While Gucci Mane cooled in a cell, his protégé OJ Da Juiceman kicked his promo game into high gear.

title: Birdseed Shirt
label: What Delicate
description: Ferocious and brave, this debut LP is a well-balanced demonstration of both thoughtful existentialism and strange, drowsy downers.

title: Grrr...
label: Dead Oceans
description: Bishop Allen's 2006 monthly EP series suggested a band of educated romantics. Here they aim to replicate that on their new LP.

title: Reincarnations: The Remix Chapter 2001-2009
label: Get Physical
description: Like Battles' Mirrored, this Kompakt remix album delights in the goofy-unto-surreal things electronics can do to the human voice.

title: Angst Is Not a Weltanschauung!
label: Morr
description: Even while recording in the wake of a friend's death, this Morr mainstay's complex, nuanced tunes don't lose their subtle uplift.

title: Kaleidoscopic
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: The leader of underrated post-rock combo Jaga Jazzist follows Joanna Newsom or Robert Wyatt by occupying the ambiguous region between classical music and pop.

title: Face Control
label: Sub Pop
description: On every conceivable level-- even down to the cover art-- the new LP from Wolf Parade-related Handsome Furs bests its predecessor.

title: Drone Trailer
label: Dicristina
description: Matthew Valentine, who rose to a kind of freak-folk prominence as Tower Recordings, returns with partner Erika Elder.

title: Communion
label: Yep Roc
description: Sweden's unabashed retro rockers release a 24-song 2xCD album. Seriously, 24 songs.

title: As Seen Through Windows
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Arcade Fire-related band enlists Tortoise's John McEntire and expands its cinematic scope and orchestration.

title: Fuckbook
label: Matador
description: Despite outward appearances, this is the new covers record from indie rock legends Yo La Tengo.

title: Assemble
label: Joyful Noise
description: Disjointed guitar rhythms, unpredictable drumbeats, and strained soprano vocals make unavoidable the comparison to Deerhoof.

title: Thank You Very Quickly
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Thrill Jockey releases another seamless blend of American rock music with benga, Kenya's ebullient and propulsive dance music.

title: (a)spera
label: K
description: Latest from Pac NW singer-songwriter is marked by lush sound and diverse instrumentation.

title: Little Hells
label: Kemado
description: Marissa Nadler's elegant new album is also her most expansive, with production that sharpens old strengths while exposing new ones.

title: Song of the Pearl
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Thrill Jockey's Arbouretum tone down both guitar heroics and song lengths while honing lyrics and song structures.

title: The Truth Is Here
label: Rhymesayers
description: Collecting B-sides and outtakes along with new material, this EP finds rapper Brother Ali mixing political commentary and shit-talking.

title: Mama, I'm Swollen
label: Saddle Creek
description: After another three-year break, Cursive return with a straight shot of melodramatic misery and despair, leavening the shouty intensity with orchestration.

title: Ye Viols!
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Jan St. Werner of Mouse on Mars compiles recent works commissioned to accompany art installations.

title: Carboniferous
label: Ipecac
description: Mike Patton recruits Italy's most progressive no-wave metal bands (as far as we know) to his eclectic Ipecac roster.

title: Beat Konducta Vol. 5-6
label: Stones Throw
description: Madlib pays tribute to the late J Dilla, a producer with whom he created the classic Champion Sound.

title: Songbook
label: End of the Road
description: Hushed folk-pop with orchestral flourishes and the occasional whimsically long song title mark this Calgary band's debut.

title: Glider
label: Ghostly
description: Seattle artist inverts the minimal techno aesthetic of Gas-- burying the thump and emphasizing the ambience.

title: The Law of the Playground
description: English band follows The Best Party Ever with more sunny harmonies and anorak pop.

title: Frontier
label: Manimal Vinyl
description: Part cosmic fun house, part haunted house, Danielle Stech-Homsy's sophomore release began as a series of poems.

title: Surf City EP
label: Morr
description: A New Zealand band paying tribute to Kiwi bands of the past, Surf City are a glorious throwback with a sense of purpose.

title: Wavvves
label: Fat Possum
description: One-man noise-pop project Nathan Williams delivers on his first widely released LP.

title: Secrets Are Sinister
label: Original Signal
description: New York band's latest again infuses turn-of-the-millennium Strokes moves with more bombastic stadium rock.

title: The Good Feeling Music of Dent May and His Magnificent Ukulele
label: Paw Tracks
description: Mississippi native's debut on Animal Collective's Paw Tracks imprint finds him working in the realm of schmaltzy barroom pop with a style that's sometimes evocative of Jens Lekman or Stephin Merritt.

title: Shrag
label: Where It's At Is Where You Are
description: Brighton, UK's Shrag are a sharp, up-and-coming poppy post-punk band smearing their own dark lip gloss on sex and gender while also looking for real, vital connection.

title: Reviver EP
label: Post Present Medium
description: On their debut, L.A.'s Abe Vigoda made self-described "tropical punk," mixing steel drum-mimicking guitars and stilted, hard-to-play rhythms; on this new EP, the band takes the next logical step in the development of their easy-to-peg sound: they abandon it.

title: Middle Cyclone
label: Anti-
description: Middle Cyclone

title: My DNA
label: Retard Disco
description: Bis keyboardist and singer's first solo album finds her still experimenting with variations on the bright, kandy pop of her former band.

title: Here We Go Magic
label: Western Vinyl
description: Luke Temple's new project finds him letting his psychedelic impulses take over, as he adds hazy electronic textures, loops, and extended bits of ambience and noise.

title: Labyrinthes
label: Dare to Care
description: Montreal band follows its breakout sophomore album, Trompe-l'Oeil, by amping up the prog with multipart mini-epics and jarring structural changes.

title: No Line on the Horizon
label: Interscope
description: No Line on the Horizon

title: Tchamantché
label: Nonesuch
description: Tchamantché

title: Super Roots 10
label: Avex Trax
description: Super Roots 10

title: The Blue Depths
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Jagjaguwar band leaves behind most of its melodramatic art-rock moves, showing a newfound restraint and a rich and sumptuous sound.

title: I Want to Go Where Things Are Beautiful
label: Twos & Fews
description: I Want to Go Where Things Are Beautiful

title: To Be Still
label: Rough Trade
description: To Be Still

title: Dark Was the Night
label: 4AD
description: Red Hot comp features Arcade Fire, Spoon, Feist, Decemberists, Cat Power, Antony, Bon Iver, members of Sigur Rós, and many others.

title: Choral
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Brooklyn-based drone duo offers up their most coherent album yet, balancing organic instrumentation with percolating electronic undercurrents.

title: An Imaginary Country
label: Kranky
description: An Imaginary Country

title: Invaders Must Die
label: Take Me to the Hospital
description: Invaders Must Die

title: Jean on Jean
label: Kanine
description: Former Out Hud cellist Molly Schnick drops almost everything about her former band on this new project, a collection of strummy bedroom chamber-pop.

title: Recordings 1969-1988
label: Faitiche
description: The first release on experimental electronic producer Jan Jelinek's label Faitiche, the homemade recordings of the late Ursula Bogner might never have been heard outside her immediate family had Jelinek not discovered them, or recorded them and conceived the entire backstory himself, depending on who you ask.

title: Hungry Bird
description: Originally slated as the final album from Eef Barzelay's Clem Snide, which may or may not be defunct, Hungry Bird substitutes the band's erstwhile lighthearted alt-country with more sober, standard folk fare.

title: The Century of Self
artist: ...And You Will Know Us by the Trail of Dead
label: Richter Scale
description: The Century of Self

title: How Will You?
label: Drag City
description: On her third Drag City solo album, Azita scraps most of her Steely Dan-like tendencies for a more traditional (if subtly unnerving) take on cabaret-pop.

title: The Mountain
label: Fat Possum
description: With Spoon producer Mike McCarthy behind the boards, this blues-rock band from Dayton, Ohio, aims for a slightly cleaner sound to accompany songs that are a touch more introspective.

title: The Ultimate Peter Tosh Experience
label: Schanachie
description: With two DVDs alongside an oddly selected 14-track audio disc, The Ultimate Peter Tosh Experience isn't exactly what is claims to be.**

title: 200 Million Thousand
label: Vice
description: 200 Million Thousand

title: Wrecking Ball
label: Razor & Tie
description: Georgia band purees alt-country tropes together with the muddy crash of grunge on their debut full-length.

title: I Don't Know Where I'm Going But I'm on My Way
label: Humminbird
description: The Old 97s bass player releases his solo debut, a collection of originals and mostly covers that employ trains as vehicles for a spiritual journey and that sounds more musically adventurous than anything his band has done.

title: Astral Weeks Live at the Hollywood Bowl
label: Manhattan
description: One of rock's most legendary cult records, Astral Weeks has now inspired a series of concerts and an inevitable live document honoring those shows.

title: God Loves Ugly
label: Rhymesayers
description: God Loves Ugly

title: Exodus
label: Expansion Team
description: This debut album by filmmaker and media production head Alex Moulton scores an imagined science-fiction adventure with classic Vangelis and French House flourishes.

title: Davy
label: Young Baby
description: Actor Jason Schwartzman-- who, to be fair, was making music before he was making movies-- returns with another rewarding small-scale pop project, reminiscent of 60s British Invasion artists and 90s artists like Elliott Smith and Weezer who aped them.

title: Incredibad
label: Interscope
description: Incredibad

title: sBach
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: Spencer Seim, guitarist for Hella and drummer for the Advantage, here takes multi-instrumentalism to its logical conclusion, playing every instrument on this Suicide Squeeze release.

title: ...For the Whole World to See
label: Drag City
description: ...For the Whole World to See

title: Studio 1
label: Studio
description: A collection of early techno tracks by German scenemaker and Kompakt co-owner Wolfgang Voigt (aka Gas) marks an embrace of formalism as a way toward something new.

title: Jason Isbell and the 400 Unit
label: Lightning Rod
description: On his second solo album, the former Drive-By Truckers member sticks with what he does best, offering detailed and evocative songwriting in a bar-band setting.

title: The Spirit of Apollo
label: Anti-
description: The Spirit of Apollo

title: Emerald Eyes
label: self-released
description: This placid and peaceful Texas-based duo favors molasses-slow keyboard drones and heavily reverbed vocals, sometimes evoking the dreaminess and eerie ambience of Beach House or Julee Cruise.

title: Black Forest (Tra La La)
label: Science of Sound
description: Stripping down orchestral pop to something acoustic and approachable-- much like fellow Wisconsinites Violent Femmes did with punk a quarter-century ago-- Pale Young Gentlemen make nice strides on their second album.

title: Tight Knit
label: Sub Pop
description: The fourth album (first for Sub Pop) from this folk-rock/cosmic country band is built with a keen ear for detail, be it a subtle dose of pedal steel or a gently rippling guitar effect, and it features leader Andy Cabic's most consistently engaging batch of songs to date.

title: Hush
label: Polyvinyl
description: Now a duo of Yuki Chikudate and James Hanna, Asobi Seksu return with a third album that takes the dreamy shoegaze palette of 2006's Citrus into a quieter and and more reserved place.

title: Hold Time
label: Merge
description: Hold Time

title: Anthology 1997-98
label: Dischord
description: This collection gathers stray tracks and singles from the short-lived and underrated D.C. band on Dischord that grew out of Smart Went Crazy.

title: Recitement
label: Allegro Music
description: The versatile Dutch composer Stephen Emmer, with production from Tony Visconti, combines music and spoken literary texts, with readers like Lou Reed, Allen Ginsberg, and Jorge Luis Borges tackling words by Yoko Ono, Paul Theroux, Samuel Beckett, and more.

title: Goodnight Oslo
label: Yep Roc
description: Iconoclast and leader of both the Soft Boys and his Egyptians, Robyn Hitchock again teams with R.E.M.'s Peter Buck and well-known utility player Scott McCaughey on his latest solo record. As usual, echoes of Syd Barrett, the Beatles, and Television Personalities are heard frequently.

title: Paul’s Boutique
label: Capitol
description: The Beastie Boys' landmark second album is remastered and reissued 20 years on.

title: Coastlines
label: Internasjonal
description: After remixes for kindred sprits like Low Motion Disco and the Tough Alliance, San Francisco duo Windsurf bring their brand of clean and chilled-out beachside music to Prins Thomas' Internasjonal label.

title: Major General
label: Fistolo
description: The Hold Steady keyboardist and member of the World/Inferno Friendship Society packs a lifetime of ideas into his solo debut, touching on mid-1990s alt-rock, tipsy Billy Joel balladry, Sunday afternoon swing, and Eastern European folk-tinged rave-ups.

title: Keep It Hid
label: Nonesuch
description: Keep It Hid

title: All of Us In Our Night
label: Self
description: Athens, Ga., power-poppers follow up 2005's tuneful Catalogue of Generous Men with an album noticeably darker and less immediately accessible than their debut.

title: The Singles
label: Rong
description: This Brooklyn duo-- which counts !!! singer/ drummer John Pugh as one of its members-- hit and miss on this collection of their six singles.

title: Dissolver
label: Narnack
description: After two arcane, challenging, and beautiful albums released in the beginning of the decade, this San Francisco trio reveled in their enigma status for years. Now they're back with the cleaner, leaner Dissolver. TV on the Radio's Kyp Malone and Dave Sitek help out.

title: Odessa
label: Polydor
description: Rhino's 3xCD reissue of the Bee Gees' ornate and ambitious 1969 album includes mono and stereo mixes and an extra disc of demos and previously unreleased tracks.

title: Come With Me If You Want to Live
label: Robcore
description: Pinback's Rob Crow is still pressing on with his lovingly silly metal side project; it's now moved beyond the novelty stage-- as the improved songwriting shows.

title: Come Back to the Five and Dime, Bobby Dee Bobby Dee
label: Domino
description: Singer-songwriter's second album veers from doo-wop and folk to Queen bombast to tell the story of the tragic life and lonely death of Disney child actor Bobby Driscoll.

title: To Willie
label: Dead Oceans
description: Matthew Houck, aka Phosphorescent, follows three fine LPs of original songs with a tribute to the Red Headed Stranger, Willie Nelson.

title: In the City
label: Cash Money
description: Ca$h Money release a rock album; not surprisingly it sounds like N.E.R.D. or a body spray commercial. Nas, Rick Ross, and Lil Wayne guest.

title: Afro Samurai Resurrection
label: Wu Music Group
description: The follow-up to 2007's manga soundtrack Afro Samurai, Resurrection finds RZA working with many of his Wu-Tang cohorts.

title: Mirror Eye
label: Social Registry
description: Contemporaries of Gang Gang Dance and Black Dice, NYC's Psychic Ills here fully indulge their abstract tendencies, eschewing all traditional means of songcraft for a record that is almost wholly improvised.

title: Month of Madness
label: self-released
description: Philly rapper compiles 32 well-written, expertly produced tracks-- released once per day for the month of December-- into the overlooked Month of Madness mixtape*.*

title: The Crawling Distance
label: Guided By Voices, Inc.
description: Robert Pollard and Todd Tobias continue a working relationship that has enjoyed its share of recent successes, most notably 2006's From a Compound Eye and last year's Robert Pollard Is Off to Business.

title: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
artist: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart
label: Slumberland
description: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart

title: Changing Horses
label: ATO
description: As the title suggests, here Ben Kweller jumps from making polite, mannered 1960s-influenced indie-pop to polite, mannered 1970s influenced alt-country.

title: Love, Hate, and Then There's You
label: Majordomo
description: Five long years on from Pawn Shoppe Heart and their alt-rock moment, the Von Bondies reemerge with a stern-faced intent and self-belief that sounds more like the Killers than their former friends and contemporaries the White Stripes.

title: Leave It All Behind
label: Nicolay Music
description: North Carolina MC Phonte and Dutch producer Nicolay continue their partnership with an unexpected left-turn, crafting a surprisingly strong full-on R&B record with almost no rapping.

title: Devastator
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Chicago-based bar band on Secretly Canadian adds some additional instrumentation on their second full length, but still lives and dies on the strength of lead singer George Hunter's voice.

title: RTZ
label: Drag City
description: Ben Chasny illuminates the more neglected corners of his dense discography on the 2xCD/triple-vinyl set RTZ, which takes from split 12" releases, subscription-only CDs, and Chasny's personal tape stash, plus a reissue of 1999's Nightly Trembling album, whose original release (as legend has it) was limited to 33 copies.

title: Never Better
label: Rhymesayers
description: Fusing hip-hop and punk, the third solo record from this Minneapolis-based rapper and member of the Doomtree collective is his tightest album yet.

title: The Time of the Assassins
label: Ryko
description: Strokes bassist Nikolai Fraiture is the latest member of the band to start a side project. Regina Spektor and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner guest.

title: Clomeim
label: Locust
description: Veterans of the tape-trading and micro-label cultures, No Neck Blues Band have been releasing music for more than a decade but this is oddly only their fourth proper studio album-- and it finds the band touching on metal's sonic heft and under-surface collision.

title: The Singles, Vol. 6: 1969-1970
label: Hip-O Select
description: The latest in this Hip-O series finds James Brown in transition and caught in many minds, recording essential sides even when he made off-the-wall choices.

title: Decent Work for Decent Pay
label: Big Dada
description: This selection of Diplo's remix work-- including refits of tracks by Daft Punk, M.I.A., and Bloc Party-- highlighs a bunch of songs you likely have on MP3 or a mixtape, plus a surprisingly deft selection of instrumental work.

title: Years of Refusal
label: Lost Highway
description: Morrissey and his Tormentors continue their 21st century winning streak with a record that, while offering no new twists or surprises, finds the former Smiths co-leader in strong voice-- both as a singer and songwriter.

title: Immolate Yourself
label: Bpitch Control
description: Telefon Tel Aviv's latest-- released on the heels of the death of bandmember Charles Cooper-- is a detailed and smartly programmed reimagining of 1980s synth-pop.

title: Paranoid Cocoon
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: Michael Nau, ex-Page France leader, releases the first LP from his new project. The countrified atmosphere and vocal trade-offs with Whitney McGraw fall somewhere between Johnny Cash and June Carter and Yo La Tengo circa *And Then Nothing Turned Itself Inside-Out.*

title: Boombox
label: Parlophone
description: Kylie Minogue's 2000s resurrection as an electro-pop superstar is celebrated on this remix collection, which includes reworkings of her songs from artists such as the Chemical Brothers and Fischerspooner.

title: Ray Guns Are Not Just the Future
label: Blue Note
description: The second album from L.A. scenesters the Bird and the Bee sticks close to their original template, with more cool electro-exotica flecked with global pop touches.

title: Sparklace
label: Polyvinyl
description: Drummer from Aloha and White Williams releases his second solo offering, a departure from his brainy, ambient 2006 debut Illuminated Manuscript, that augments his cerebral beats with charming melodies and glassy, glammy grooves of his day-job bands.

title: You and I
label: Frenchkiss
description: After moving to London, abandoning their hardcore roots, and hooking up with ex-Suede guitarist Bernard Butler as producer, this spirited, young New Zealand rock band is finally ready for its close-up.

title: Stay Awake EP
label: Matador
description: Neither a coda nor a collection of cast-offs or curios, this five-song EP lays out five fresh new cuts worthy of any Times New Viking LP. And, hell, you can even pick out a lyric or two.

title: Take Me to the Sea
label: Matador
description: Take Me to the Sea

title: Dream Island Laughing Language
label: Marriage
description: Los Angeles-based duo, whose conceptual work is often discussed in the context of Animal Collective, release a sketchbook of their diverse musical influences that throws a lot of stuff at the wall; it's remarkable how much of it sticks.

title: Dear John
label: Polyvinyl
description: On his new album, indie-twee songwriter Loney Dear taps a surprising a vein of melancholy...and it suits him.

title: How Little Will It Take
label: Load
description: Collecting an out-of-print LP with live tracks and compilation appearances, How Little Will It Take makes a convincing case that Providence's Landed were the proper heirs to the Jesus Lizard's noise-rock throne.

title: Traitors
label: Relapse
description: Misery Index's latest album wraps the band's precise, melodic blend of death metal and grindcore around a progressive political message.

title: Skin of Evil
label: Soft Abuse
description: As Blackout Beach, Carey Mercer (Frog Eyes, Swan Lake) retains his careful attention to scope and language but here stays on task and creates something gloriously claustrophobic and engaging from start to finish.

title: Flower of Evil
label: Rune Grammofon
description: Susanna (sans her Magical Orchestra) tackles another slate of cover songs comprising unlikely selections from Tom Petty, Thin Lizzy, ABBA, and more. Will Oldham duets on several tracks, including a version of his Bonnie "Prince" Billy song "Joy and Jubilee".

title: The Thrush
label: Obey Your Brain
description: Members of stalwart Chicago acts like Mahjongg, Icy Demons, and Mucca Pazza come together to create mostly instrumental Moog-laden space-funk.

title: Gutter Tactics
label: Ipecac
description: Ipecac indie hip-hop group return with another set of verbal bluntness and sonic brutality, helping to color the fringes of rap with musical and political gusto.

title: Working on a Dream
label: Columbia
description: Bruce Springsteen's work this decade first played up to listeners' notions of post-9/11 recovery, then conjured up bleak visions of Bush-era America; here the Boss settles into some sense of contentment on Working on a Dream, as if that Dream had already been achieved.

title: Dragon Chinese Cocktail Horoscope
label: SideCho
description: Singer-songwriter's fourth album, again co-produced with Scott Solter, finds him paring back his sound and opting for a markedly darker feel.

title: Oh, the Places We'll Go
label: K
description: Twee-ish band on K consists of pop dreamers of an unusually levelheaded kind, while their music moves between between faster-paced glee-club soul and trippier, jazzier reveries.

title: Johnson&Jonson
label: Tres
description: Mixing invocations of youthful indiscretion and coming-of-age epiphanies, Los Angeles rapper Blu and producer Mainframe create one of the best and most underrated underground hip-hop records of the past six months.

title: All We Could Do Was Sing
label: self-released
description: Oakland, Calif., art-pop outfit returns with a full-length of nautically-themed songs; while there is an overriding narrative supported by enough real life experience to tell the tale, the band is smart enough to weave its way in and out of the story whenever it's convenient.

title: At Mount Zoomer
label: Sub Pop
description: The two distinct, exceptional songwriters in Wolf Parade-- Dan Boeckner and Spencer Krug-- combine to create a record that seems focused on skewing darker, on sounding nastier, more perilous, and less straightforward than its predecessor, 2005's Apologies to the Queen Mary.

title: Body Language
label: Drag City
description: Tel Aviv-based hard rockers with an over-the-top live show debut on record with an EP on Drag City.

title: How We Lost
label: Secretly Canadian
description: While it continues their steady drift from post-rock to melodic indie pop, Windsor for the Derby's eighth full-length is still diverse enough to suggest that they never want to be any one kind of band.

title: Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends
label: Capitol
description: In a case of well-honed troubleshooting after the startlingly bland X&Y, Coldplay's fourth LP is a diluted version of U2's Achtung Baby or Radiohead's Kid A, the "experimental" mid-career maneuvers of their peers. Brian Eno produces.

title: Go Out Tonight
label: Rhythm of Life
description: Josef K's erratic leader steps out with an album about the disappointments of going out.

title: Flight of the Knife
label: Black and Greene
description: Bryan Scary's second album sucks in all kinds of 1970s rock-- the canonic glitter-rock of Sparks and Queen, the MOR pop of Wings and ELO, and the fleet-fingered prog of Yes and early Genesis. The end game is not so much prog as power-pop with chops.

title: Seeing Sounds
label: Interscope
description: The new album from the Neptunes' rock project can be backhandedly complimented as a comeback of sorts by mere virtue of not being noticeably worse than what came before it.

title: Parallel Play
label: Yep Roc
description: The latest from veteran power-poppers Sloan, Parallel Play, is in a strange position of being a follow-up to a breakthrough album-- 2006's ambitious Never Hear the End of It-- that never really broke through.

title: Tha Carter III
label: Cash Money
description: Nine years after his first solo LP, and on the heels of an unprecedented glut of increasingly remarkable mixtape and internet leaks, Lil Wayne produces Tha Carter III, the epic culmination of a lifetime of eccentricities. This is Wayne's moment and he embraces it on his own terms.

title: Charmed & Strange
label: Verve Forecast
description: Israel-born singer-songwriter who infuses his acoustic pop tunes with beats wants to be a "one-man Timbaland band." Well...

title: Small-Time Machine
label: self-released
description: The first physical release from the Brooklyn-based one-man electro-pop project, last heard from on the download-only One Alternative covers EP.

title: Laulu Laakson Kukista
label: Fonal
description: Finnish collective on the Fonal label scatters Europop, rustic folk, pastel electronics, and woolen drones like a tossed deck of playing cards.

title: Takes
label: Domino
description: Adem, aka the guy from Fridge who isn't Four Tet, puts aside post-rock and neo-folk long enough to record Takes, a largely acoustic album of unpretentious covers rendered more emotionally than cerebrally. Among the artists tackled on the 90s-heavy collection are Björk, Smashing Pumpkins, PJ Harvey, Aphex Twin, the Breeders, and Tortoise.

title: EP
label: self-released
description: EP

title: The Door Into Summer
label: Language of Stone
description: More folk-prog Rennaissance fair music from the folks at Language of Stone, all dressed up and looking backwards.

title: Noise Won't Stop
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: New York synth-pop/dance-rock duo seem blissfully unconcerned about touching on the right reference points here on their latest, which was originally issued in the UK in 2007 and is now out in North America via Kill Rock Stars.

title: Diamond Hoo Ha
label: Astralwerks
description: Britpop's most flat-out enjoyable band continue to learn to age gracefully, here working with Bad Seeds producer Nick Launay, who showcases a harder yet still familiar image of the group.

title: Robert Pollard Is Off to Business
label: Guided By Voices, Inc.
description: Robert Pollard's latest-- which he claims will be his only 2008 release-- showcases the prolific songwriter at his most conventional, leaning heavily on long-time producer/ multi-instrumentalist Todd Tobias and his lush, expansive arrangements.

title: Welcome
label: Stones Throw
description: James Pants, the first Stones Throw intern-turned-roster member, creates a willfully odd debut album that, no matter what you ultimately think of it, deserves to be heard.

title: Voyager
label: Sony
description: Chicago electro-poppers, fresh from having two songs featured on "Ugly Betty", issue a debut full-length that grows more interesting as it progresses.

title: In Between Words
label: Kranky
description: Following a path blazed by Morton Feldman, this Canadian composer essentially turns the familiar Romantic-era music of the 19th and early-20th centuries inside-out. This is his second album on Kranky.

title: The Dream
label: Six Degrees
description: The Orb have presented The Dream as a return to both form and freedom. On the one hand, they cut loose from the deadening expectations of record labels and made it themselves; on the other, they've promised the fans a return to the cosmic roamings of their 1990s peaks.

title: Evil Urges
label: ATO
description: My Morning Jacket have refused to remain creatively static, a decision that's helped them map a clear and wonderful upward trajectory over their first decade, but does them few favors on their baffling new album.

title: Huggable Dust
label: Absolutely Kosher
description: After his twin 2005 debuts High Road and Low Road, singer-songwriter Marty Anderson returns with a chamber-pop album filled with songs about love.

title: Get Better
label: Asian Man
description: Buffalo foursome parties like it's 1993, bringing to mind bands like the Breeders and Belly with songs that feel social and conversational but don't take themselves too seriously.

title: Worldwide
label: Ninja Tune
description: Hitching revved-up buzzsaw guitars to machine-gunned low-budget beats, Baltimore's Death Set-- denizens of Dan Deacon's Wham City-- manage the difficult trick of competently fusing rap and punk rock.

title: New Amerykah Part One: 4th World War
label: Motown
description: The first in a series of pointedly social records from Erykah Badu, this fascinating, sonically adventurous album finds her exploring a post-Civil Rights landscape in which African-Americans have been left to sort out how to have a cultural identity as part of a nation that had, up until very recently, been a dedicated adversary. Madlib, 9th Wonder, and Shafiq Husayn are among the producers.

title: Fleet Foxes
label: Sub Pop
description: Following their spectacular Sun Giant EP, Seattle-based Fleet Foxes' full-length debut has a lot to live up to. Luckily, it more than delivers the goods: Incorporating a broad spectrum of styles-- from Appalachian folk and AM country to classic rock and SoCal pop-- Fleet Foxes create a personal synthesis of the music of their peers, their parents, and even their grandparents.

title: Superabundance
label: Ryko
description: Nattily-dressed English band that shares the post-punk reverence of Bloc Party and Futureheads returns with its second album.

title: Thing of the Past
label: Gnomonsong
description: This Vetiver covers album not surprisingly digs exclusively in the crate marked "1967-1973", culling its tracks from the catalogs of artists like Hawkwind, Townes Van Zandt, and Michael Hurley.

title: Nah Und Fern
label: Kompakt
description: This 4xCD box set collects the four albums that Wolfgang Voigt has created under his Gas moniker-- 1996's self-titled record, 1997's Zauberberg, 1998's Königsforst, and 2000's Pop-- and collectively they represent a wondrous high point in the history of electronic music.

title: Maybe They Will Sing for Us Tomorrow
label: Darla
description: Imagine if an audio tape, unraveled and stretched out in the breeze, could capture the sound of its own undulations. That's what the perfectly named Hammock sound like.

title: 12 Angry Months
label: Shout! Factory
description: Scott Lucas looks back at a year of romantic misery with shocking candor.

title: Come, Arrow, Come!
label: Language of Stone
description: Alexis and Lindsay Powell, sibling masterminds of Brooklyn folk outfit Festival, implore listeners to "make fun with these ladies of the forest night."

title: Watershed
label: Roadrunner
description: Swedish prog-metal greats unexpectedly fly their freak flag on their ninth full-length.

title: Rook
label: Matador
description: Much more than one man's solo recordings or an Okkervil River side project, Jonathan Meiburg's Shearwater follow last year's partially re-recorded and re-released Palo Santo with their first LP of new tunes for Matador.

title: Wild Animals
label: Nacional
description: The Spanish band's pan-genre versatility and fearless pursuit of fun is reminiscent of Super Furry Animals or the 1990s' internationalist indie pop of groups like Pizzicato Five and Cibo Matto.

title: The Acrobats
label: Static Cult
description: Second album from two members of defunct slowcore outfit Duster contains a wider range of emotions than its predecessor, showcasing surprisingly sharp (but sedated) pop chops carefully preserved in amber.

title: Directions to See a Ghost
label: Light in the Attic
description: Austin's Black Angels create a sprawling, psychedelic record dotted by gloomy invocations of warfare, betrayal, paranoia, and self-obsession.

title: Youth Novels
label: LL
description: The latest in a line of fine Swedish pop exports, Lykke Li's debut album-- which, although it seems like it's been around forever, is only just now out in the UK with a U.S. release to finally come this summer-- was produced and co-written by Björn Yttling of Peter Björn and John.

title: Songs in A&E
label: Interscope
description: After a five-year absence-- in part due to being hospitalized with double pneumonia-- Jason Pierce returns with another LP of love songs, drug songs, and God songs, producing his best record in a decade.

title: Sun Down
label: Team Love
description: Nik Freitas' fourth album-- and first for Conor Oberst's Team Love imprint-- was written and recorded at a home studio that he lovingly created piecemeal via Craigslist.

title: Heartcore
label: Leaf
description: Swedish husband-and-wife duo Andreas Werliin and Mariam Wallentin offer a debut album on Leaf composed of his compact drum work and her orbital, precise vocals.

title: Velocifero
label: Nettwerk
description: Ladytron follow the expansive, immediate Witching Hour with a record of more restrained goth-pop.

title: Weezer (Red Album)
label: DGC
description: Weezer (Red Album)

title: Tragicomic
label: Sunnyside
description: Jazz pianist and Mike Ladd collaborator Vijay Iyer's compositions tend to mix moody textural passages with bursts of odd rhythm, some that even sound like riffs.

title: A Mouthful
label: Cinq7
description: The Paris-based duo of Finnish expat Olivia Merilahti and French multi-instrumentalist Dan Levy offer a pleasantly surprising album that tries to balance the immature and the grown-up.

title: What Does It All Mean? 1983-2006 Retrospective
label: Illegal Art
description: Illegal Art, home of Girl Talk, celebrates sampling pioneer Steinski, who took hip-hop's tradition of reformatting existing material and made it a postmodern funhouse.

title: II Trill
label: Rap-A-Lot
description: After UGK became one of the few truly feel-good comeback stories in rap, Pimp C's death made Bun B, for the second time in his career, a solo artist not by choice but by necessity, and he's responded with a record that greatly improves on 2005's Trill. Guests include Lil Wayne, Lupe Fiasco, David Banner, 8Ball & MJG, Killer Mike, Mike Jones, and Pimp C.

title: Live at the Royal Albert Hall
label: Ninja Tune
description: Ornamented with an army of vocalists and a 24-piece orchestra, this trip-hop outfit has assembled an unyieldingly classy live recording that nonetheless hints at some fundamental problems.

title: Desert Crossroads
label: Riverboat
description: This sextet's potent nomadic blues is a blend of two West-Central African ethnic groups-- the Tuareg and the Wodaabe peoples-- who historically have lived in the south Sahara and Sahel grasslands. Where the Tuareg band Tinariwen spin their desert blues with strong rock overtones, Etran Finatawa keep things more traditional.

title: Lay It Down
label: EMI
description: Producers and session players Ahmir "?uestlove" Thompson and James Poyser of the Roots team with The Greatest Living Soul Singer and manage to evoke the supple groove of Al Green's early-70s classics.

title: This Is Not the World
label: Nul
description: After parting ways with 679 Recordings, the Futureheads eagerly started their own label, Nul Recordings, and have released this economy-size power-pop album.

title: Songs on the Rocks
label: Get Physical
description: Songs on the Rocks

title: Dominique Leone
label: Stromland
description: Longtime rock critic (particularly for Pitchfork) mixes crafty melody with digital wizardry on his debut LP, released via Lindstrøm's Stromland label.

title: Black Wooden Ceiling Opening EP
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Phil Elverum's latest, a six-song EP in part made of reworked older material, is a bright spot in a sometimes scattered discography.

title: Imaginational Anthem Vol. 3
label: Tompkins Square
description: The first volume of Tompkins Square's series Imaginational Anthem stands as a high-water mark of the contemporary American Primitive guitar movement. This is volume three.

title: Gods of the Earth
label: Kemado
description: On the follow-up to debut album Age of Winters, the Sword seem acutely aware of their indie-metal tag, doing everything they can to ratify the will of the people who tossed that crown on their heads in the first place.

title: Lie Down in the Light
label: Drag City
description: Will Oldham's latest could be the evil twin of the singer/songwriter's career peak, 1999's I See a Darkness: If that 90s record plumbed the bleakness of life, Lie Down in the Light finds peace in the modest pleasures of friends, family, and music.

title: Shine
label: Atlantic
description: Shine

title: You May Already Be Dreaming
label: Saddle Creek
description: Bright Eyes associates' third full-length is their first on Saddle Creek, and their brand of earnest, countrified indie brings to mind an earlier time in the label's history.

title: Memory Drawings
label: Temporary Residence
description: The second full-length from this San Francisco post-rock quartet, who have toured with labelmates Explosions in the Sky and Mono, skirts dub, krautrock, and jazz while remaining difficult to pin down.

title: Crystal Stilts
label: eMusic
description: Weirdly life-affirming and very fun, Crystal Stilts are moody-sounding fuckers who make fabulous stripped-down, C86-like garage-pop.

title: DISCO
label: Lovepump United
description: HEALTH's debut album attempted to artfully reconcile dance/digital elements with rock/noise textures. The group goes one step further on this remix album, which features contributions from Crystal Castles, Acid Girls, Thrust Lab, and many more.

title: Inherit
label: Ecstatic Peace
description: The first album in more than 10 years from Sonic Youth's Kim Gordon and Pussy Galore's Julie Cafritz-- with help this time from Boredoms drummer Yoshimi P-We and J Mascis-- finds the duo's scattershot genre-hopping whittled down to a more concise two-pronged approach.

title: Paralyzed
label: Tee Pee
description: The second album from the stoner/doom metal band featuring Dinosaur Jr.'s J Mascis on drums is harder and (in sound and in spirit) grungier than its predecessor.

title: Ghost Games
label: Gypsy Eyes
description: Despite switching frontmen Apes still sound like the same band, proof that their greatest strength-- well-honed, instantly familiar tracks-- is also their greatest limitation.

title: The Formula
label: Duckdown
description: Second full-length collaboration between Boot Camp Clik rapper Buckshot and producer 9th Wonder tries to build on the success of their 2005 album Chemistry.

title: Sool
label: Bpitch Control
description: The Bpitch Control owner's latest record is uncompromising, barren, and austere-- and another success in a career full of them.

title: Faces of the Night
label: Menlo Park
description: After playing avant-pop that fused Brooklyn's best out-music tendencies and four-track bedroom twee, Flying now settle for careerist indie pop.

title: Yes, U
label: Beggars Banquet
description: Berlin-based, Australian expats move from atmospheric neo-goth to something that-- although it still feels in line with Tindersticks or Nick Cave-- sounds both classic and singular.

title: Soul Messages from Dimona
label: Numero Group
description: The latest excellent Numero Group release is a 16-track compilation of soul music, sure, but it's also music intertwined with the histories of Israel, Liberia, the Black Hebrew movement, Zionist emigration, and black art and culture in Chicago.

title: The Bake Sale EP
label: Chocolate Ind.
description: Chicago's the Cool Kids finally release their long-awaited, self-produced Chocolate Industries EP, out now on iTunes and in stores early next month.

title: The Virginia EP
label: Beggars Banquet
description: The National take a victory lap with an unnecessary collection of demos, B-sides, live tracks, and covers, none of which fully capture the group's strengths and appeal.

title: Autumn Fallin'
label: Blue Note
description: Like logorrheic, New York-based folk-popsters Regina Spektor, Nellie McKay, and Casey Dienel, Jaymay sings winsome, quasi-confessional songs that the linguistically lazy probably tag "quirky."

title: Ames Room
label: Fat Cat
description: Bergen bedroom auteur used an array of instruments and equipment, some of which she either found or constructed herself, to craft her anticipated Fat Cat debut.

title: Terrible Two
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On their first album for Thrill Jockey, these Baltimore art-punks with drum chops offer cluttered rhythms, speechless chanting, and unrelenting spasms of guitar noise.

title: Strange Hexes
label: self-released
description: Former member of Lowercase, Alaska!, and the New Folk Implosion-- and touring guitarist for the Yeah Yeah Yeahs-- again tries his hand as a frontman.

title: Cheveu
label: Born Bad
description: Spirited French band with a fondness for noise moves from delectably trashy drum-machine punk tunes to Casio experiments that reverberate in slow, strange ways.

title: Anywhere I Lay My Head
label: Rhino
description: Actress Scarlett Johansson unveils her anti-vanity vanity project, a record of Tom Waits covers (with one original) that belongs as much to its producer, TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek, as it does to the Lost in Translation star. If this isn't weird enough already, the Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner and David Bowie are among the guests.

title: Taro Tarot EP
label: HOSS
description: Ex-Liars and n0 Things member Pat Noecker continues here to make blunt, visceral rock/punk tropes feel like a vague out-of-body experience.

title: Most Valuable Player
label: Broken Sparrow
description: Former Dirty Projector and experimental music vet takes a set of his most battle-tested material and applies raw performances to his polished compositions. Former bandmate Dave Longstreth guests and Grizzly Bear's Chris Taylor produces.

title: Re-Arrange Us
label: Barsuk
description: Far from the runaway-mine-car frenzy that defined some of their early work, the husband-and-wife duo of Kori Gardner and Jason Hammel opt for slower tempos, multi-instrumental arrangements, and overdubbed harmonies on their fifth full-length.

title: Lie in Light
label: Kranky
description: Lie in Light

title: All Together
label: Hometapes
description: Three records into its career, this mathy Philadelphia outfit has created an accessible album that nonetheless sounds unlike what any other band is doing.

title: You Cross My Path
label: self-released
description: Tenth album by the long-running outfit, available as a free download, has all of the band's trajectories-- Madchester, Stones-inspired classic rock, Britpop-- meeting up at the same intersection.

title: Poisonous Times
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: On their third full-length, Poisonous Times, Old Haunts add former Bikini Kill drummer Tobi Vail to tighten up their already compressed sound.

title: Faint at the Loudest Hour
label: VHF
description: While based on acoustic guitar, very little about the album is pure, conservative, or provincial; instead, Turnquist embeds both new age and noise-oriented electronic themes into his pastoral pieces.

title: Silent Movie
label: !K7
description: The thin line between schmaltz and beauty is something musicians have had to grapple with for a while. Working together as Quiet Village, Matt Edwards of Radio Slave and his collaborator Joel Martin strike just the right balance, transforming easy listening sounds of the past into the soundtrack to the finest 3 a.m. trip home you'll have all year.

title: Warchild
label: Interscope
description: London resident who fled South Sudan releases his second album to coincide with screenings of a new documentary about his life; while some songs deal with the horrors he witnessed as a child solider, others concern culture shock and his struggles in the first world.

title: I Wish That I Could See You Soon EP
label: Everloving
description: Herman Dune-- which consists of Franco-Swedish singer David-Ivar Herman Dune and drummer Neman-- have sharpened their craft without becoming overly professional or disingenuous. On their new EP*,* they play deceptively simple folk-based compositions with flashes of electric guitars, horns, mouth harp, and bowed saw.

title: The Master's Bedroom Is Worth Spending A Night In
label: Tomlab
description: Here the undercooked folk of the band's 2006 release The Cool Death Of Island Raiders is jettisoned for an album of a very particular sort of desert summer, as influenced by oil stains and scorched blacktop every bit as much as gutbucket garage and primordial rock.

title: Ringer
label: Domino
description: Latest from Kieran Hebden is a mini-album that leans toward 4/4 techno, but, as usual, he seems less interested in developing genres than in absorbing their tropes into his own hermetic sound world.

title: The Slip
label: self-released
description: Trent Reznor returns with yet another digital record; The Slip is a free download that, unlike the sprawling loss-leader Ghosts I-IV, consists of fully realized songs. Pretty good ones, too.

title: Freedom Wind
label: Dead Oceans
description: More than a decade after the likes of the High Llamas and the Elephant 6 groups helped revive interest in the Beach Boys' psychedelic period, and only a year after Panda Bear's Wilson-tripping Person Pitch, the Explorers Club celebrate the band's sun-soaked early singles.

title: Sexuality
label: Record Makers
description: Willing to embrace artifice and genre-hop well beyond his expected limitations, this French producer returns with an erotic synth-pop album of unexpected charm and grace.

title: Momofuku
label: Lost Highway
description: Elvis Costello releases his first Imposters album in a while, and it's the best of all that would imply-- a fiercely melodic record that sinks or swims on the dynamics of his band. Jenny Lewis guests.

title: Narrow Stairs
label: Atlantic
description: Death Cab's second album for Atlantic and sixth proper LP overall is one of the darkest and most muscular in the band's discography, as they move from the undergraduate longing of their earlier work and the looming mortality of Plans to a more generalized existential angst.

title: Vainajan Muotokuva
label: Fonal
description: From Finland's Fonal, a label typically known for abstract electro-acoustic and improv, comes a trio offering an art-disco rollercoaster.

title: Otis Blue: Otis Redding Sings Soul [Collector's Edition]
label: Rhino
description: Otis Blue: Otis Redding Sings Soul [Collector's Edition]

title: Films
label: Definitive Jux
description: Originally a Japan-only release, the follow-up to 2000 debut Sanity Annex by underground hip-hop project Sonic Sum has been unavailable in the States for the past four years.

title: My Bloody Underground
label: A
description: Given its title, it's fitting that this self-produced record attempts to emulate both the gauzy atmospherics of My Bloody Valentine and the sparse efficiency of the Velvet Underground.

title: Supreme Balloon
label: Matador
description: They're still working with an overriding concept, but this time Martin Schmidt and Drew Daniel of Matmos focus on a simple aesthetic limitation: using only synthesizers as input sources. While there's little in the way of outside text to grapple with as a result, the decision opens the door on some gorgeous sonic shifts.

title: What I Want From You Is Sweet
label: Language of Stone
description: On her debut album, Dommisse sounds like a fanciful bard in the Joanna Newsom mold, an electric cello player singing narrative set pieces about twin girls telling ghost stories; but something dark and serrated is hidden among all those would-be costume folds.

title: Tickley Feather
label: Paw Tracks
description: The brainchild of Philadelphia native Annie Sachs, Tickley Feather creates scratchy bedroom probings that slot nicely next to fellow Paw Tracks alum Ariel Pink, yet she's not nearly as musically dynamic or engaging as the kingpins of her loose coterie, Animal Collective.

title: The Evangelist
label: Yep Roc
description: Robert Forster's first release since the death of Grant McLennan, his late partner in the Go-Betweens, is also his best solo album.

title: Shallow Grave
label: Gravitation
description: This Scandinavian folk singer embodies the (seemingly) breezy effortlessness of early Bob Dylan, infusing his songs with a detachment that, miraculously, is neither cold nor alienating.

title: Water Curses EP
label: Domino
description: Animal Collective have followed each of their last three albums with a short companion EP closely related to its predecessor. Right on schedule, here's Water Curses, containing three tracks from the Strawberry Jam sessions and another recorded at Brooklyn's Rare Book Room studio.

title: Attack
label: Quarterstick
description: After an EP in early 2007, Attack is the debut full-length from Dave Pajo's Louisville-based metal band. His sincerity is not in question, but as to the quality of the music, well...

title: Great Plains
label: Greyday
description: Chicago band has pared back some from the gargantuan arrangements and piles of instruments that characterized its second album, 2005's Hysterical Stars, leading to some surprisingly intimate moments on their latest.

title: The Strangest Colored Lights
label: Skybucket
description: The two songwriters in this Birmingham, Ala., band come over like deep-fried Gutter Twins, and their obsession with mortality makes them musically omnivorous, as if they must digest as much as possible in their allotted time on Earth.

title: Nouns
label: Sub Pop
description: No Age follow their 2007 EP compilation, Weirdo Rippers, with an ambitious Sub Pop debut: Nouns is gorgeously thick-- a hazy, delirious expanse that's friendly and warm and, best of all, unpredictable.

title: When Life Gives You Lemons, You Paint That Shit Gold
label: Rhymesayers
description: The Minneapolis duo's surprise hit album finds them less narcissistically emo than on previous efforts; rather than himself, Slug explores a procession of rust-belt standbys-- late-shift waitress, warehouse worker, deadbeat dad, homeless man, Tom Waits-- straight out of Studs Terkel.

title: Smile
label: Diwphalanx
description: Smile

title: ¡Sonido Amazonico!
label: Barbès
description: This Brooklyn band specializes in the little-know form of chicha, which takes Peruvian folk styles and incorporates elements of Cuban and American pop and surf guitar music.

title: A Wheel Within a Wheel
label: Misra
description: Athens, Ohio's Southeast Engine see the light and release a rock opera of self-doubt and redemption.

title: The Secret Life
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Portland trio debuts strong with songs comprised of spazzy tribal-punk drums, dub basslines, shouty unison vocals, and lots of violin.

title: The Hungry Saw
label: Beggars Banquet
description: The lush, veteran noir-soul band-- reconstituted as a five piece-- here reconciles its well-established affinities with a more pastoral presentation.

title: After the Balls Drop
label: Frenchkiss
description: Not many live experiences top seeing Les Savy Fav, and the band tried to capture and house its unhinged stage madness on this digital-only release.

title: Unhistories
label: Drag City
description: Led by 90 Day Men/Lichens' Rob Lowe, and featuring two former members of U.S. Maple, this iconoclastic Drag City band aims for a sound all its own.

title: Box of Hair
label: Lookout!
description: Vancouver twee outfit's 1996 album, now reissued, is a fine showcase of the band's style: sugary three-chord indie pop, cuddly as it is catchy, with a spoonful of punk's spiky do-it-yourself energy.

title: Jim
label: Warp
description: On Jim Jamie Lidell remains obsessed with the themes of emotional imbalance, self-doubt, and dual identity that he introduced on 2005's Multiply, and the singer deepens his engagement with classic r&b across a carefully crafted set of ballads, rave-ups, and easygoing soul.

title: Opus Mixtum
label: Carrot Top
description: Antietam return with more-- a lot more-- Neil Young-meets-VU-styled gems.

title: Kensington Heights
label: Arts & Crafts
description: A more introspective and mature-sounding Constantines rebound on their fourth album and first for Canadian indie label Arts & Crafts.

title: Rising Down
label: Def Jam
description: The Roots follow their tightly-knit return to rawness Game Theory with another record that finds them coming across as intelligently aggressive firebrands, as they express precisely and without compromise an increasingly universal strain of anxiety and frustration

title: Station
label: Suicide Squeeze
description: This Chicago trio, more compact and disciplined than most of its instrumental rock peers, offers this efficient, precise Suicide Squeeze release.

title: Hello, Voyager
label: Constellation
description: Naming her new band after the title of her last solo album, Carla Bozulich returns with an avant-garde blues/metal/classical hybrid dripping with bloody catharsis.

title: Hard Candy
label: Warner Bros.
description: Having spent a decade working with producers drawn from European club culture, Hard Candy is Madonna's link-up with the American men who've come to define global pop, including Timbaland, the Neptunes, Kanye West, and Justin Timberlake.

title: Third
label: Island
description: As radical reinventions go, Third-- the first Portishead studio album since 1997-- is surprisingly natural. Darker and bleaker lyrically than their previous work, Third is a sort of re-debut-- the band's sound after it has excised every possible remnant of trip-hop from it.

title: You Are Here
label: Bluhammock Music
description: You Are Here

title: Shots
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Second album from Vancouver band shows a proclivity for Paul Bunyan-big, capital-R rock moments, with solos and crashing cymbals and howled vocals.

title: Jane Doe Loves Me
label: Cochon
description: The third release from this convulsive Oakland noise rock trio finds them getting out from the shadow of their more serene Bay Area contemporaries Deerhoof, tempering their frantic prog-punk at times with more streamlined dissonance.

title: If Children
label: Merge
description: Merge re-introduces a band whose sound-- earnest folk-influenced indie rock with touches of noise and dream-pop-- is so second-nature that nobody realizes it's actually endangered.

title: The Airing of Grievances
label: Troubleman Unlimited
description: Despite its title's implied politeness, The Airing of Grievances qualifies more as existentialism wrapped in an anti-suburban screed from a killer live band whose music is at times violent, overblown, and irreverent.

title: Ishumar
label: Realworld
description: The latest Tamashek band to wow Europe and America, Toumast are similar to desert guitar standard-bearers Tinariwen but the Parisian duo spikes its sound with rock dynamics, funky detours, and even a bit of jazz and hip-hop.

title: Mr. Love & Justice
label: Anti-
description: Billy Bragg, redoubtable radical, responds to five years of America (and England) making a mess of the world with a disc of mellow love songs.

title: Staying In
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Norwegian producer Joachim Dyrdahl-- who studied classical violin and mathematics before releasing singles on labels run by Prins Thomas and the Get Physical crew-- issues an impressive electro-disco debut for Smalltown Supersound.

title: Elephant Shell
label: Saddle Creek
description: After two years' worth of suspense-- and a few snappy EPs-- Tokyo Police Club's Elephant Shell finally arrives and finds the group waxing bookish and/or emo like fellow Saddle Creek stars Bright Eyes or the Decemberists.

title: Live in Liverpool
label: Music With a Twist
description: Live in Liverpool

title: In the Name of Love: Africa Celebrates U2
label: Shout! Factory
description: Twelve acts from across Africa pay tribute to U2, but thankfully it's better than that sounds. And it's for charity!

title: Alison Statton
label: Soft Abuse
description: Naming their album after the Young Marble Giants singer hints at what this Boston indie pop group creates: gentle understatements, stripped-down and sometimes heartbreaking.

title: Flight of the Conchords
label: Sub Pop
description: The band from HBO's "Flight of the Conchords"-- a hilarious sendup of the myth of the struggling band that came around right when the whole music biz felt blue-- is now Sub Pop's Flight of the Conchords, who have just released their self-titled debut album.

title: The Age of the Understatement
label: Domino
description: The Arctic Monkeys' Alex Turner teams with Final Fantasy's Owen Pallett, Simian Mobile Disco's James Ford, and Miles Kane, of 1960s-tinged English rockers the Little Flames and the Rascals, to create a remarkably vivid 1960s symphonic-pop pastiche.

title: Schmancey
label: What Are
description: The New Pornographers' Todd Fancey goes way back to the 1970s for a platter that ably apes the sunny side of AM radio (with a few dark clouds lurking on the horizon).

title: Bäbytalk
label: Slender Means Society
description: If the record sounds like a remarkably authentic reconstruction of the wide-eyed, freewheeling energy that attended the lo-fi British post-punk of the early 1980s, it's because Alig Pearce is no newcomer to this music-without-borders thing.

title: Reality Check
label: Merok
description: Reality Check

title: The Show
label: M3
description: Rap supergroup features 41-year-old Juice Crew vet Masta Ace, Lyricist Lounge hands Wordsworth and Punchline, and Milwaukee MC Stricklin; together, they've produced an epic, heart-breakingly honest update on their lives.

title: We Appreciate You
label: Frenchkiss
description: Frenchkiss band continues its jagged turn through post-punk, singing about hoping to escape from their boring lives, falling in and out of love, making friends, sleeping in, and getting their shit together.

title: The Blood Pressure Sessions
label: Dual Plover
description: Australian band making its way to the States via the Stiltbreeze label churns out primitive, stripped-down post-punk with a touch of dark humor.

title: Uneasy Flowers
label: Kranky
description: Autistic Daughters here make an incremental improvement over their fine 2004 debut Jealousy and Diamond and, despite being a song-based entity, evoke the soothing drift of fellow Kranky stalwarts like Stars of the Lid.

title: Dazzle Ships
label: Virgin
description: One of British pop's more notorious flops, OMD's misunderstood gem is also ripe for revisionism: It's got a strong backstory, it's as ambitious as it is catchy, and it even has a gorgeous Peter Saville sleeve.

title: SVN FNGRS
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: Frank Black returns again to his Pixies-era stage name and a change in direction, steering away from the rootsy rock of the Catholics and his sedate recordings with legendary session musicians and back toward surging, punk-inspired weird-rock on this new mini-LP.

title: Konk
label: Astralwerks
description: The Kooks follow their popular debut Inside In/Inside Out with another record borne of the same old Kinks/Jam boys-club ethos.

title: Plunder, Beg, and Curse
label: Fat Possum
description: After an EP that recalled the swooning guitar-driven romanticism of artists like Jeff Buckley and early Radiohead, Colour Revolt return with their ambitious debut full-length.

title: Move Every Muscle, Make Every Sound
label: Roadrunner
description: Sophomore effort from this Nashville band is pared back and more focused, leaning on the group's more hooky power-pop sound.

title: The Seldom Seen Kid
label: Geffen
description: Elbow's fourth album doesn't rock the boat so much as steadily alter the waves, with surprisingly good results.

title: Red
label: Polydor
description: Ambitious England-based band follows the effusive, vivacious, and Mercury Prize-nominated Through the Windowpane with a record that downplays sprawling orchestration for a tighter, harder, more jarring sound.

title: The Mande Variations
label: World Circuit
description: Only the second solo album from kora master Toumani Diabate, The Mande Variations pays tribute to influences both centuries old and of a more recent vintage, with brilliant, beautiful results.

title: Remix Romance Vol. 1
label: Paper Bag
description: This collection-- the first of two Sally Shapiro remix sets this year-- is an accomplished, occasionally revelatory recasting of Disco Romance's synth-pop by some of contemporary electronic music's most capable hands, including Junior Boys, Lindstrøm, and the Juan MacLean.

title: Saturdays=Youth
label: Mute
description: After a pair of impossibly huge, overpowering records, M83's Anthony Gonzalez changes up his sound, ditching maximalism for beauty and drama. His new album is dense with 1980s new wave tropes and teenage memories, reflecting the soft-focused mythology of eternal summers and young love.

title: Soundboy Rock
label: Sony
description: Nineties big-tent dance music holdovers wisely enlist Lady Stush and ex-Sugababe Mutya Buena to help pepper their latest album with charm and sass.

title: The Air Salesmen
label: International Hits
description: The Selmanaires have grown up in the burgeoning Atlanta indie scene nearly step-for-step with the Black Lips; playing the ego to the latter's id, the Selmanaires show off a (slightly) more civilized musicianship as they explore several decades' worth of genres here on their second album.

title: Midnight Organ Fight
label: Fat Cat
description: Glasgow indie pop band (is there any other kind of Glasgow band?) follows its slept-on and charming debut Sing the Greys with another assured set of soulful barnburners and aching ballads.

title: In Ghost Colours
label: Interscope
description: Blog house may be increasingly used as an eye-rolling pejorative, but don't punish Cut Copy's hugely enjoyable In Ghost Colours, a fantastic summer pop record that feels light, confident, and unencumbered by the dictates of fashion.

title: Feel Good Ghosts (Tea-Partying Through Tornadoes)
label: Earthology
description: The environmentally conscious collective's eighth album in eight years is a marked departure from previous records.

title: Pershing
artist: Someone Still Loves You Boris Yeltsin
label: Polyvinyl
description: Armed with a memorably silly name and all the right blogger friends, this Polyvinyl band made waves in 2005 with a sound so collegiate you can practically hear an awkward DJ announcing the title between pockets of dead air after every song.

title: Keep Your Eyes Ahead
label: Sub Pop
description: One of the year's pleasant surprises and biggest sleepers, the latest from this Sub Pop group is full of lilting rock songs performed with the measure and craft of Northwest scene veterans.

title: Neptune
label: You Are Here
description: After the charming improbability of their 2005 debut, the Duke Spirit's Neptune aims to prove the group is ready for its close-up.

title: Music for Lamping
label: Audio Dregs
description: Paul Dickow returns with another album from his diverse and rewarding Strategy project, but this time he fully commits to a sense of ambiance at the expense of its rock signifiers.

title: Antidotes
label: Sub Pop
description: Foals' debut, like many British records, trails clouds of homeland hyperbole. The press is calling them "math rock" and the band members have cited Gwen Stefani and Steve Reich, but Foals are squarely in a more recent and less exotic tradition: the hi-gloss end of the post-punk revival.

title: Walk It Off
label: XL
description: Like Clap Your Hands Say Yeah before them, blogosphere darlings Tapes 'n Tapes have enlisted famed producer Dave Fridmann to helm their much-anticipated sophomore album.

title: In Light
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Former Tussle member Alexis Georgopoulos reinvents himself as the architect of an early 1970s throwback to a time when electronics seemed warm, friendly, natural, perhaps inevitable, and above all optimistic.

title: Asking for Flowers
label: Zoe
description: Of all the female singer-songwriters who inhabit the borderland between actual country and general roots music, few have as much presence as Canadian Kathleen Edwards.

title: Mountain Battles
label: 4AD
description: The follow-up to 2002's Title TK-- a tentative first step back into the public eye after nearly a decade of inactivity-- Mountain Battles finds Kim and Kelley Deal proudly flaunting their bull-headed perseverance and their familiar arsenal of quirks, hiccups, sputters, and enthusiasm.

title: The Last Tycoon
label: Wichita
description: One-third of Peter Bjorn and John follows his group's breakthrough with a folk-pop solo album loosely inspired by the final, unfinished novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald, a sad tale of a workaholic, studio-era Hollywood mogul.

title: The Felice Brothers
label: Team Love
description: The Felice Brothers perfectly replicate the old, weird Americana of Bob Dylan and the Band, a Phyrric victory.

title: Excuse Me, This Is the Yah Mos Def
label: My Pal God
description: Coming on like License to Ill-era Beastie Boys, these vegans from the Philadelphia hardcore scene have built hard-edged, DIY party tracks out of cheap, scratchy beats.

title: Rabbit Habits
label: Anti-
description: Man Man follow their breakthrough Six Demon Bag with their self-confessed "pop record," an album that hints at maturation without eschewing the group's unique tics.

title: Sings Live!
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: The Decemberists singer offers his third solo, acoustic record-- the first two found him covering Morrissey and Shirley Collins-- and handles the material with a blend of irony and self-effacement that becomes its own kind of very modern charm.

title: Disintoxication
label: Goodfellow
description: This Italian band's 2004 debut was relatively brighter, with an angular, metallic hardcore punk framework and a sophisticated harmonic sense that suggested musical training behind its tattoos; Disintoxication drops most color for a hundred shades of black.

title: Nigeria Special: Modern Highlife, Afro-Sounds & Nigerian Blues
label: Soundway
description: Two discs of obscure but stellar Nigerian pop and rock from the country's creative golden age, compiled by Soundway, the folks behind the awesome Ghana Soundz comps? Yes, please.

title: Do It!
label: Domino
description: Despite the fact that there's still some old reliable structures underpinning Do It!, this new album might be Clinic's most adventurous since Internal Wrangler.

title: Dig!!! Lazarus Dig!!!
label: Anti-
description: This is how rock musicians are supposed to age.

title: Love Is Real
label: Upset the Rhythm
description: Longtime underground music figure and recent Ariel Pink associate puts a bizarre and creepy spin on synth-pop wherein the tragic collides with the ridiculous in the most garish way possible.

title: A Sense of Purpose
label: Koch
description: The Swedish metal band continues to broaden its appeal and embrace a more mainstream sound, to the despair of some of its longtime metal fans.

title: Little Death
label: Stolen
description: Reading band's name is reminiscent of the British Invasion, but its music recalls the Clean and other Flying Nun stalwarts funneled through 1990s U.S. indie rock. The Go! Team's Gareth Parton produces.

title: One Hell of a Ride
label: Columbia
description: Taking in the full half-century breadth of the country legend's career, this 4xCD, 100-track set reminds us why you just don't say no to the red-headed stranger.

title: The Glow Pt. 2
label: K
description: K Records reissues Phil Elvrum's quiet masterpiece, a record of intuitive music and esoteric flights of the imagination. The set also features bonus material recorded in 2007 specifically to accompany this release.

title: Savage Life 2
label: Trill Entertainment
description: Fitting for an album that documents a perhaps unwilling crawl to maturity, the Baton Rouge rapper's second solo record succeeds when it sticks to the specific, discrete, and (relatively) adult.

title: Cold & Kind
label: Parasol
description: Like Belle and Sebastian or Sufjan Stevens, this Chicago band is known more for great arrangements and delicate lyricism than a visceral pull.

title: Electronic Projects for Musicians
label: Elephant Six
description: Offering material from as far back as 1995, this rarities collection scoops up a decade's worth of compilation tracks, Japan-only bonus songs, and other ephemera, including the band's 2006 ode to Stephen Colbert.

title: Last Night
label: Mute
description: A concept album that serves as a nostalgic trip down clubland lane, Moby's latest attempts to distill a quarter-century of NYC dance music into one hour.

title: Flock
label: Interscope
description: This is the stateside debut-- and third release overall-- from a band that, OMG, used to feature Damien Rice.

title: Cover Up
label: 13th Planet
description: Although 2007's The Last Sucker was Ministry's final album of original material, this odd coda-- a covers record that finds the group tackling Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones, ZZ Top, Mountain, and Deep Purple, among others-- may be more of a statement.

label: Social Registry
description: On their debut album, this London band charts transformations from psych-rock and pastoral folk to free-jazz breakdowns, pounding Afro-tech grooves, and avant-classical composition.

title: Ghosts I-IV
label: The Null Corporation
description: Trent Reznor's defection from the music business might be the best thing that ever happened to him financially and ideologically. Aesthetically, Reznor's move is, so far, reminiscent of Prince's a decade ago-- his first new self-released project is a two-hour, 4xCD instrumental work.

title: Demonstration Tape (1997-2007)
label: Ghostly
description: This 2xCD set documenting the last decade of Jason Amm's electronic pop project is remarkably consistent, almost to a fault.

title: Innocent Youths
label: Summer
description: The latest entry in Light in the Attic's Jamaica to Toronto series focuses on the Summer Records house band who, in 1977, cut this, the first album released by the Canadian label.

title: Everywhere at Once
label: Anti-
description: The best parts of Everywhere at Once show this Solesides alum as a lighthearted yet substantially energetic vocal presence at the center of a big, shameless funk record.

title: Attack & Release
label: Nonesuch
description: The Delta-tinged garage band's latest record-- created with producer Danger Mouse-- was originally conceived as a collaboration with the late Ike Turner. What remained following Turner's death became the foundation of their fifth and most adventurous album to date.

title: Consolers of the Lonely
label: Warner Bros.
description: Announced and released within a week, the sophomore record from Jack White and Brendan Benson's band features stuffed arrangements, big hooks, and even bigger guitars.

title: Only as the Day Is Long
label: Sub Pop
description: Former member of the defunct Carissa's Wierd returns with her second solo album; while she's not always able to escape the shadows of luminaries Cat Power and Lisa Germano, there are plenty of nicely evocative moments to be found here.

title: Supercluster: The Big Dipper Anthology
label: Merge
description: Featuring members of Dumptruck, the Embarrassment, and Volcano Suns, Big Dipper wrote songs about hunting down the Loch Ness monster and destructive house parties; Merge gives them the reissue treatment they deserve.

title: Live 1969
label: Columbia
description: Released exclusively to Starbucks with a wider release planned tentatively for this fall, Live 1969 collects Simon & Garfunkel performances from a six-city run, which culminated in a two-night engagement on their New York home turf.

title: Accelerate
label: Warner Bros.
description: R.E.M. acknowledge a few misteps with their 14th album Accelerate, trading the sleepy studio experiments of their recent LPs for renewed vigor and louder guitars.

title: Trilla
label: Def Jam
description: Second album from the Miami rapper whose name rhymes with "boss" is unsurprisingly terrible. Lil Wayne, Young Jeezy, and Trick Daddy guest.

title: Hawk Medicine
label: Temporary Residence
description: San Fran space-folk sets the controls for the heart of despair.

title: Debt Dept
label: Paw Tracks
description: Excepter's first release on Animal Collective's Paw Tracks label plays up the group's strengths-- rolling loops, clicking drum machines, and droning synths deftly woven together.

title: J2
label: The End
description: Two of the most prolific, restlessly creative, and influential artists in underground music join forces; the result sounds closest to Jarboe's dark, gothic electronics.

title: At All Ends
label: Load
